newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslavia to reinforce measures against "grey economy".
newsitem.headline: Yugoslavia to reinforce measures against "grey economy".

text.p: Yugoslavia on Friday reiterated its commitment to fight the "grey economy", which accounts for 40 percent of its GDP, and said it would soon announce long-term measures against illegal business.

"The federal government has taken a series of steps to fight the grey economy and will soon release medium and long-term measures to return most illegal activities to legal economic channels," Yugoslav Interior Trade Minister Milora Miskovic told a news conference.
"We want to reduce the grey economy to 10-20 percent of GDP, considered as an acceptable share of gross domestic product."
Miskovic insisted only economic measures could successfully stifle illegal activities.
The government plans to tackle the problems of different taxes and the huge share of cash in circulation in M1 money supply as key areas on which the grey economy was feeding.
The government called on the central bank and finance ministry to reduce the share of cash in circulation in M1 money supply, currently 45-46 percent.

All importers will be obliged to pay import and excise duties, and a sales tax at the border crossings where goods enter, while the federal customs office will tighten control of incoming goods at all border crossings.
State inspectors, police and army will help them supervise illegal border crossings, Miskovic said.
Yugoslavia first pledged to curb its booming grey economy early in 1997. -- Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 311 4254
